Award.AwardTitle: ERASynBIO:ECF Express - An Orthogonal, Organism-independent Expression Platform Based on Extractoplasmic Function (ECF) Sigma Factors

Division.LongName: Div Of Molecular and Cellular Bioscience

Award.AbstractNarration:
The defining characteristics of synthetic biology are both the application of engineering principles to advance biological understanding and to develop new functions for useful purposes. One of the major challenges of synthetic biology is to modify or create new biological systems that are more efficient and reliable than natural organisms. This research project addresses one such challenge through the design and implementation of new regulatory modules that will control and optimize gene expression without wasting cellular resources. Significant broader impacts of this research are educating a next-generation workforce to support a growing bioeconomy, providing a new fundamental understanding of an important biological process, and generating new enabling tools for the wider synthetic biology community.

This research takes advantage of a new process of using extracytoplasmic function sigma factors for synthetic biology applications. These extracytoplasmic function sigma factors (ECFs), when redesigned, can serve as robust gene regulatory switches capable of controlling diverse transcriptional activities. These factors have two conserved protein domains that recognize and bind to specific promoter sequences. They then recruit RNA-polymerase to initiate transcription from natural or synthetic promoter sites. The compositional simplicity of these factors are used for creating a series of synthetic sigma factor/promoter pairs tailored for specific regulatory needs. In this project, the investigators will create chimeric ECFs from natural ECFs to generate a large library of universal switches that are orthogonal in four model bacteria (E. coli, S. meliloti, B. subtilis and S. venezuelae). This will be accomplished by applying design strategies based on combinatorial synthesis, structure-guided mutational approaches and in vivo and in silico testing in complex genetic circuits. This results will provide new tools to enable biological design via synthetic biology. This project is the US collaborative component of a project funded through the ERASynBIO EU-US transnational funding mechanism.

POR.DRECONTENT:
Like all living organisms, bacteria express proteins encoded by their genomes through an RNA intermediate. The steps from DNA to RNA (transcription) and from RNA to protein (translation) are used to regulate the amount and timing of protein production. For example, an organism may only make an enzyme used for digesting a certain sugar in the presence of that sugar. In bacteria, much of this regulation happens at the transcriptional (DNA to RNA) level. Like all living organisms, bacteria use a multi-subunit RNA polymerase and a dissociable specificity subunit. This dissociable specificity subunit directs the RNA polymerase to the start (promoter) of each gene that should be made. In bacteria, this specificity subunit is called sigma factor. Because of its central role in transcription, every bacterium must have at least one sigma factor (called the housekeeping sigma factor). However, many bacteria have multiple sigma factors. These multiple sigma factors recognize different promoters and partition the transcriptional space, effectively turning on groups of genes that function in the same process or respond to the same stress.  

Extracytoplasmic function (ECF) sigma factors are the largest and most diverse family of sigma factors, with up to 150 ECF sigma factors in a single bacterial genome. Many of these ECF sigma factors carry out stress responses, but they have also been implicated in virulence, differentiation, and other diverse processes. Unlike housekeeping sigma factors, ECF sigma factors show high promoter specificity and recognize relatively few promoters. Although the promoter specificity and regulons of a few ECF sigma factors have been determined, the vast majority of ECF sigma factors remain uncharacterized.

Taking advantage of the autoregulatory nature of many ECF sigma factors as a means of promoter discovery, we generated an aligned collection of ~50,000 ECF sigma factor sequences and their putative auto-regulatory promoter motifs. We used this collection to discover specific amino acid – nucleotide interactions that are important for promoter recognition in ECF sigma factors. Based on this data, we individually predicted the promoter specificity of ~100,000 ECF sigma factors across >20,000 bacterial species. We scanned these generated motifs across the relevant genome, and determined statistically significant targets for a majority of ECF sigma factors using a newly developed computational method for ascribing significance to transcription factor hits across genomes. Analyzing this vast collection of statistically significant ECF sigma factor regulons, we find that we both recapitulate existing biology and extend what is known about ECF sigma factors regulons across the bacterial kingdom.

This knowledge of ECF sigma factor regulons can be leveraged in several ways. First, understanding what genes are regulated in response to a specific stress can tell us what kind of damage is caused by that stress and how bacteria respond to that damage and make themselves resistant. For example, if we know that bacteria respond to DNA damage using a light-dependent DNA repair system, we can adjust the use or dosage of DNA damaging antibiotics to situations where bacteria have no light. 

Second, seeing what genes are expressed together can suggest functions for genes of unknown function. For example, we find that a particular sigma factor is important for regulating fatty acid metabolism. We can therefore guess that the genes of unknown function regulated by the same ECF sigma factor are involved in fatty acid related processes.   

Third, understanding how ECF sigma factors recognize DNA can help us build sigma factors that turn on certain genes at certain times. This can be helpful for synthetic biology applications when genes for making various compounds need to be turned on in the right order. In such a case, you would want several sigma factors that recognize different promoters. Taken together, the research above has substantially increased our understanding of ECF sigma factors, both for engineering application, and in their role function in diverse bacteria.

Finally, this project served as a training ground for college students and technicians. During the summer of 2016, Horia trained an undergraduate student, Kira Patterson, in cloning and experimental work. Kira is an undergraduate at an excellent small college with limited research opportunities.  She is considering a career in the health sciences, and with Horia’s help has become immersed in the lab, learning cloning and transformation techniques, basic lab skills, and participating fully in lab meetings. In 2017, a technician, Jennifer Doherty, was also involved in the project, helping with cloning and learning some bioinformatics in order to help with pieces of the pipeline. Her experience in the lab led her to pursue a PhD in biology at Stanford University.
